There are numerous taxonomic studies that have been conducted for Acanthopagrus, with several species complexes identified, including, Black Seabream forms I-II and Yellowfin Seabream forms I-II (Iwatsuki 2013).

This species was split from A. latus, which is now recognised as five cryptic species. The five species can be distinguished from one another by the counts of dorsal-fin rays, pore lateral-line scales, scale rows between the fifth dorsal-fin spine base and lateral line, and other distinguishing morphological characteristics and body and fin coloration (Iwatsuki 2013).

The Acanthopagrus latus complex has recently been split to include five cryptic species: A. latus (distributed in east Asia), Acanthopagrus longispinnis (Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes 1830) (northern Gulf of Bengal Bay), and three new species, Acanthopagrus morrisoni, Acanthopagrus arabicus, and Acanthopagrus sheim. Ophiclinops pardalis appears to be the sister species of O. hutchinsi, with which it shares generally high counts for meristic characters, a large maximum size, and similarity of colour pattern. Ophiclinops hutchinsi is known only from Western Australia while O. pardalis is known only from eastern Australia. These two species should be synonymized when specimens at localities between the two areas of known distribution are examined and if the populations have intermediate fin-ray and vertebral counts between O. hutchinsi and O. pardalis. Elops machnata and E. hawaiensis occur sympatrically in the Western Pacific and possibly the Hawaiian Islands, so further research appears warranted. In Japan, for example, Sato and Yasuda (1980) claim that E. machnata historically reported in the region are misidentifications of E. hawaiensis.

Elops saurus was recently split into two largely allopatric species, E. saurus and E. smithi (McBride et al. 2010). In Florida waters, E. saurus and E. smithi may occur sympatrically at early life stages, though this does not appear to persist into the adult stage (McBride and Horodysky 2004).  E. saurus and E. smithi can be differentiated by myomere or vertebral counts;  the more northern E. saurus is characterized by a higher count while the more southern E. smithi exhibits a lower count (Smith 1989, McBride and Horodysky 2004, McBride et al. 2010). These phenotypic differences are corroborated by genetic data (McBride et al. 2010). The sequence divergence in mtDNA cytochrome b (d = 0.023-0.029) between E. smithi and E. saurus is similar to or greater than that measured between recognized species of Elops in different ocean basins (McBride et al. 2010). We recommend the vernacular name Malacho, which is already used for Elops in several countries bordering the Caribbean basin." (McBride et al. 2010; see 'etymology').

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

According to Miller (1986) and Kovačić (2004) Gobius strictus Fage, 1907 is a junior synonym of Gobius cruentatus Gmelin, 1789. The status of three small syntopic gobiid species (Gobius assoi, Gobius strictus, and Cabotichthys schmidti) was clarified by Miller (1967, 1973). Miller (1967) concluded that Gobius assoi De Buen, 1936 is a junior synonym of Cabotichthys schmidti (De Buen, 1930), and that this species should be assigned to genus Gobius. Miller (1973) later considered Gobius schmidti (De Buen, 1930) a junior synonym of Gobius strictus Fage, 1907, and not a valid species. Finally, Miller (1986) further developed his opinion and suspected that Gobius strictus Fage, 1907 not to be a valid species, but misidentified juveniles of another, larger Gobius, Gobius cruentatus Gmelin, 1789.

Studies of the morphology of juveniles and early juveniles of G. cruentatus confirmed that there was almost no differences between juveniles of G. cruentatus and the morphology given in the description of G. strictus. Without further evidence to justify the validity of G. strictus it should be considered a junior synonym of G. cruentatus (Kovačić 2004, M. Kovačić pers. comm. 2014).

The specimen FMNH 61897 was erroneously listed as a paratype by Ibarra and Stewart (1987). The species was originally described by Richardson and Jowett (1951) as Myxine biniplicata based on a 315 mm dissected female and a second small and damaged specimen measuring approximately 163 mm total length (TL).

The three foremost teeth confluent at the base is given by Günther (1870) as a character of M. australis (but occurs in only one 490 mm specimen from Sandy Point, which was selected by Regan (1913) as the lectotype of M. tridentiger. Based on the recent examination of all type series, the paralectotypes BMNH 1868.6.15.5-6 from Sandy Point (Punta Arenas) were re-identified as Myxine affinis, and paralectotypes BMNH 1868.9.16.12-13 from Tyssen Islands as Myxine knappi (Mincarone unpublished data).

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

Many authors reported the occurrence of polibranchiated hagfishes in Chilean waters under the species name polytrema. However, these citations pertain to unrecognizable species in that neither count had useful proportions or color notes provided. A complete list of names and references of these unassignable records was provided by Wisner and McMillan (1988), which also contains citations under the species name dombey (Gastrobranche dombey La Cepède, 1798) or dombeyi (Gastrobranchus dombeyi Shaw, 1804), an unrecognizable myxinid from Chile.

The very similar and closely related (sister) species occurring around Saint Helena Island is Thaloassoma sanctaehelenae. Thalassoma ascensionis has also been recorded as occurring around Sao Tome Island in the Gulf of Guinea (Afonso et al. 1999), though the species in this latter area is almost certainly T. newtoni. Occurrences listed from Ghana and Congo probably also refer to the latter species, and those from Senegal to T. pavo, which also occurs in the Cape Verde Islands and northwards to the Azores, including in the Mediterranean sea (Bernardi et al. 2004, Castagliola et al. 2004).

The degree of genetic separation between Polyprion americanus populations in the Atlantic, and those occurring in the southern Pacific (Australia and New Zealand) is similar to the degree of separation seen between P. americanus and congener P. oxygenios. Given ongoing developments in genetic sequencing, further examination may re-define Polyprion systematics.

There has been confusion regarding the validity of Cynoglossus microphthalmus and this nominal species. Menon (1977) considered C. microphthalmus to be a junior subjective synonym of Cynoglossus capensis, though he noted several characters to distinguish these nominal species. Barnard (1925) also noted differences between characters of specimens that he identified as Trulla microphthalmus compared to those of C. capensis, however, he did not consider these differences to be significant enough to recognize two species. Further study based on additional material is needed to resolve this taxonomic question (T. Munroe unpublished data). Munroe (unpublished data) considers the morphological differences sufficient to recognize both as valid species.

It has since been reported in several books and checklists from Central America (e.g. Castro-Aguirre et al. 1999, Munroe 2003, Angulo et al. 2013), but the basis of these records and the number of additional specimens is uncertain. The taxonomic status of this nominal species requires further investigation (Munroe 2003); for example, Robertson and Van Tassell (2019) suggested that this nominal species may be conspecific with Citharichthys arenaceus.

Research is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of these two nominal species.

Hippocampus pontohi was described from and originally thought to be restricted to Central Indonesia and West Papua. There are now records of the species from more widespread locations, including the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, and Fiji. At times there have been specimens from PNG identified as H. colemani. Given the morphological overlap between specimens of the two, further morphological and molecular work needs to be done to ensure that these are in fact distinct species. Hippocampus colemani would take precedent if the two were deemed the same, as it was described earlier.

Papaconstantinou pers. comm. 2007). The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be 1-2 hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

There is a type locality but no type specimens which has created confusion in the identification of this species. We follow Eschmeyer's conclusion that N. coibor is a good species and concur that it is a valid name (K. Carpenter and N. L. Chao pers comm 2018).

Atrobucca marleyi was described on the basis of a single specimen collected from South Africa. It has been treated previously as a synonym of A. nibe and as a valid species. More research is needed to verify the validity of this species. See also the Red List assessment of A. nibe for further taxonomic explanation.

Umbrina canariensis and U. ronchus were once recognised as separate species but taxonomic and genetic work (Hutchings and Griffiths 2005) have shown that these are one species with the correct name being U. robinsoni. The name Umbrina canariensis belongs to a separate, deep-water species.
Identification of species of Nibea is difficult, and records of this species outside of the Fujian Provence need to be verified (K. Sasaki pers. comm. 2016).
Acanthopagrus catenula was previously thought to be a southern population of A. bifasciatus but was recently validated as a separate species (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2011).

The name H. coronatus has often been applied to H. sindonis in the past. Morphometric (Lourie et al. 1999) and genetic (Mukai et al. 2000) research suggest that these two are not the same species. Mukai et al.’s (2000) data also suggest that H. coronatus is distinct from H. mohnikei.

Although the names Hippocampus subelongatus and H. elongatus were first described in the same document, there are apparently no type specimens for H. elongatus, and thus Hippocampus subelongatus is the proper name (Lourie et al. 1999, Eschmeyer et al. 2017).
Lourie et al. (2016) placed H. montebelloensis into synonymy with H. zebra.

This species is named in honour of Miss Satomi Onishi, the dive guide who collected the type specimens (Lourie and Kuiter 2008). Lourie et al. (2016) placed Hippocampus waleananus into synonymy with H. satomiae.
Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). This species was recently split from E. boehlkei (Victor 2013).

The taxonomy of all Stenogobius species is in flux, with about 30 nominal species (and only a few of these probably valid) and the genus in great need of review. Stenogobius gymnopomus is often misidentified in books and online databases under a variety of names.

There are no issues regarding the validity of the species, but it should be noted that it is often confused with Elops lacerta (Whitehead 1990). Elops senegalensis and E. lacerta occur sympatrically across the entire range of E. senegalensis, so further research appears warranted.

Even though Elops lacerta and Elops senegalensis occur sympatrically across the entire range and appear confusing with each other they can always be distinguished by number of scales on the lateral line; 92-100 for E. senegalensis and 72-83 for E. lacerta (Paugy et al. 2003).
At times confused with Glossogobius giuris (see Maugé 1986). Two of the syntypes from India are different species (H. Larson in press).
The family Bathylaconidae is not monophyletic (Poulsen et al. 2009).

This species' taxonomic status is under review. It is now only known from the holotype, which is in such a poor state that it can no longer be used for comparison to other specimens (J. Nielsen pers. comm. 2014).

Ongoing taxonomic work is expected to confirm that Mirapinna esau actually represents juvenile specimens of Procetichthys kreffti, and therefore, is its senior synonym (Johnson et al. 2009, Paxton et al. 2016).
May be known by the older name Paruroconger drachi.
The taxonomy of this species is not currently well understood. Hymenocephalus gracilis is a synonym of Hymenogadus gracilis in the Catalog of Fishes.

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one to two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

Taxonomic revision of the genus Bathyonus is needed in order to verify species distributions (Nielsen et al. 1999). Nielsen et al. (2008) collected an specimen from the Southern Ocean, but did not describe it past the genus level because of unresolved taxonomic issues within the genus.

The type specimen in British museum could not reliably be identified to the species level as the specimen is in poor condition and is a juvenile (11.4 mm SL). This species is undetermined and is likely a junior synonym.

This species has long been synonymized with Hippocampus ramulosus Leach 1814. The most recent and comprehensive taxonomic reviews suggest there are only two European species, H. guttulatus and H. hippocampus, and that each is a single undifferentiated species across its range (Woodall et al. 2018). Riquet and colleagues (2019) evidenced the existence of five clearly distinct genetic lineages of  H. guttulatus: one from North Sea to southwestern France, one around the Iberian Peninsula to the Alboran Sea, one in the Black Sea, one in the Mediterranean Sea, and the last limited to Thau and other Occitania lagoons in southern France. Further research is needed to understand if this has taxonomic incidences and to establish if H. ramulosus is a different species of H. guttulatus or a different morphological type (Woodall et al. 2018).

The most recent and comprehensive taxonomic reviews suggest there are only two European species, Hippocampus guttulatus and Hippocampus hippocampus, and that each is a single undifferentiated species across its range (Woodall et al. 2018). However, three distinct genetic subpopulations of H. hippocampus have been identified: in the English Channel and Bay of Biscay, Europe including the Mediterranean, and West Africa (Woodall et al. 2011).

Syngnathus euchrous is thought to comprise two subspecies: S. euchrous euchrous and S. euchrous ollotropis. The physical difference between the two is in number of dorsal rays, tail rings and rings covering their brood pouch (S. e. euchrous having slightly more rays and rings). In regards to range and habitat, S. e. euchrous is found in the northern part of the species’ range, off rocky shores; while S. e. ollotropis is found in the southern part of the range, in eelgrass beds and drifting algae. The separation point between the two varieties is between Punta Eugenia and Bahia Tortugas, Baja California, Mexico. Syngnathus euchrous is also closely related to S. leptorhynchus (Fritzsche 1980).
The Order for this Family has changed  from Syngnathiformes to Gasterosteiformes (Nelson 2006).

Kuiter (2000) regarded the Indonesian and Western Australian forms of S. lettiensis to be separate species. According to his taxonomy, the Indonesian form retains the original name Solegnathus lettiensis Bleeker, 1860 (the type was from Indonesia), and the Western Australian form should be classified as Solegnathus guentheri Duncker, 1915. Pogonoski et al. (2002) treated the two forms as one species, citing that the only difference described by Kuiter (2000) was colour pattern. The two forms are treated here as one species.

Preliminary investigations into the taxonomy of this species suggest that the true Solegnathus hardwickii is restricted to the South China Sea and Japan (the type specimen is from China). It has been suggested that there may be two undescribed species, one distributed on the east coast and the other on the west coast of Australia (Kuiter 2000). Until the taxonomy is resolved, we have treated Solegnathus hardwickii as one species which occurs in all the areas mentioned below.
This species was recently separated from Synodus doaki and described as a valid species known only from the Hawaiian Islands (Randall 2009).

Starksia springeri has been recently described. It was originally known as S. atlantica, now shown to be a species complex comprised of S. atlantica, (known from Bahamas and Turks and Caicos), S. sangreyae (Belize) and S. springeri (Curacao) (Baldwin et al. 2011).

The generic assignment of the new species to Liopropoma is tentative pending the results of an extensive genetic and morphological study of the Serranidae family currently in progress (Baldwin and Johnson 2014).

The generic assignment of the new species to Liopropoma is tentative pending the results of an extensive genetic and morphological study of the Serranidae family currently in progress (Baldwin and Johnson 2014).

The single specimen from Shark Bay differs in a some features including color differences noted above and in having cycloid scales on the nape and operculum. Counts agree with other specimens of the species. The specimens may represent a separate species and are not included in the type series (Hoese and Larson 2010).
Originally placed under genus Halaelurus and subgenus Bythaelurus. Bythaelurus has now been elevated to generic level.

White, Ebert, and Compagno (2008) described the Western Gulper Shark (Centrophorus westraliensis) in 2008, as it previously had been considered to be synonymous with Centrophorous harrissoni McCulloch, 1915.

The Flagtail Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium signourum) was described by Last et al. (2008) and was previously referred to in part as Cephaloscyllium sp. E in Last and Stevens (1994). In that volume, this species was thought to also occur off northwestern Australia, but that form has since been described as Cephaloscyllium speccum Last, Séret & White, 2008. As such, C. signourum is restricted to the Western Central Pacific and is known from certainty only off Queensland, Australia. Similar forms from New Caledonia, Vanuatu and Fiji need to be critically compared with the Australian specimens in order to determine their identity (Last et al. 2008).

Previously this taxon was considered to be conspecific with Cirrhigaleus barbifer from the Northwest and Western Central Pacific. Further clarification of the taxonomic relationship between the two species is required.

The Pygmy Thornback Skate (Dentiraja flindersi) was first identified as Raja sp. M in Last and Stevens (1994) and is one of the smallest hard-nose skates. It appears to have been confused with other skate species and is a small relative of the Thornback Skate (D. lemprieri). The Pygmy Thornback Skate differs from the Thornback Skate by having an extremely broad interorbital space, nuchal thorns widely separated, and plain colour with fine white spots (Last and Stevens 2009). Some confusion remains with specimens collected from the inner continental shelf off Albany (southwestern Australia), which are most likely to be of a different species (Last and Stevens 2009).

The False Argus Skate (Dipturus falloargus) is a short-nosed Dipturus species which differs from the Ocellate Skate (Dipturus oculus) in morphometrics and the lack of a well-developed ocellus on each pectoral fin, and differs from all other Dipturus spp. in body shape and colouration (Last 2008).

The Blacktip Skate (Dipturus melanospilus) is a recently described species that is easily confused with other Australian members of the genus Dipturus, including the Pale Tropical Skate (Dipturus apricus) and Queensland Deepwater Skate (Dipturus queenslandicus) (Last and Stevens 2009).

Last and Yearsley (2002) discussed the generic placement of Australasian rajin skates. Six long-snout species were considered to conform closely with non-Australian members of the genus Dipturus. This group consists of the Bight Skate (Dipturus gudgeri), Heald's Skate (Dipturus healdi), Graham's Skate (Dipturus grahami), the Blacktip Skate (Dipturus melanospilus), Pale Tropical Skate (Dipturus acrobelus) and the Queensland Deepwater Skate (Dipturus queenslandicus). The Queensland Deepwater Skate is a problematic skate possibly involving two similar species. Unusual among Australian Dipturus skates in having the characteristic nuchal thorn either present or absent (usually present but it is easily removed). Individuals lacking a nuchal thorn can be confused with the Blacktip Skate. More specimens are required (Last and Stevens 2009).

The Sculpted Lanternshark Etmopterus sp. from Namibia and South Africa, has been referred to as E. cf. brachyurus, but is probably not conspecific with true E. brachyurus from the western Pacific (Ebert et al. 2013). This species is often confused with E. molleri and E. lucifer.
A poorly known species which is often misidentified. A similar species reported from the Western Indian Ocean may in fact represent a different species.
The taxonomy of Etmopterus unicolor remains unresolved (see Straube et al. 2011). Records from South Africa refer to E. compagnoi (Ebert et al. 2013).
Insentiraja laxipella could be generically distinct. Unique among Australian skates, in lacking dorsal fins.

The Eastern Spotted Gummy Shark (Mustelus walkeri) was recently described by White and Last (2008). It appeared in Last and Stevens (1994) as the undescribed Mustelus sp. nov. B, which was reported to occur both off western and eastern Australia. However, White and Last (2008) described the western form as M. stevensi, and the eastern form as M. walkeri.

There is uncertainty about the identification of some specimens referred to as the Ningaloo Maskray (Neotrygon ningalooensis). Those from Shark Bay (Western Australia) and Gove (Northern Territory) need to be further validated as being the same species. There is some evidence that the Shark Bay population could represent an additional species (W.T. White unpubl. data 2010), which may affect the assessment of this species, as the restricted geographic range could become more of an issue with any threats.
Closely related to Notoraja subtilispinosa but distinct in many ways.

The Network Wobbegong (Orectolobus reticulatus) was previously misidentified as the Northern Wobbegong (O. wardi) (Whitley 1939). Both species belong to a subgroup of small, morphologically similar wobbegongs, termed the ‘wardi-complex’. This species-complex contains at least three colour forms. All forms attain less than 100 cm total length and possess simple dermal lobes. Differences in colouration was initially thought to be intraspecific variation, however recent comparison of multiple specimens has shown that the forms differ consistently in colour, pattern and some morphological features. Further taxonomic and genetic research is required to elucidate the true number of species in the ‘wardi-complex’, their distributions and conservation status, but has not yet been possible due to the small number of specimens available for comparison. At this stage, the complex is considered to consist of the Northern Wobbegong, the Network Wobbegong and one (or more) potentially undescribed species (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).

The genus Parascyllium was considered to comprise of four valid species. Last and Stevens (2008) described a fifth species – Elongate Carpetshark (Parascyllium elongatum) – characterised by a very short head, no dark collar in gill region and vertical rows of white spots on the body. It was described from a single specimen collected from the stomach of a School Shark (Galeorhinus galeus) in 1990.
This ray is considered by some authors to be identical to the wide-ranging Javanese Cownose Ray (Rhinoptera javanica). Further systematic studies are required.

The Blue Legskate (Sinobatis caerulea) was recently described by Last and Séret (2008) from five specimens. Last and Séret (2008) elevated Sinobatis to the rank of genus on the basis of the conservative intragroup clasper morphology of its member species, and its strong differentiation from Hulley’s (1973) other subgenera of Anacanthobatis. This species has been provisionally placed into the genus Sinobatis in the absence of an adult male specimen.  It may have been confused in the past with the smaller Western Legskate (S. bulbicauda).

Previously considered to be a junior synonym of the Common Stingray (Dasyatis pastinaca), this species differs in disc shape, shape of the dorsal skin fold, and form and number of oral papillae (Last et al. 2016b).

Scorpaenodes guamensis and S. scaber have been recorded widely in the Indo-West Pacific. In the literature, greyish individuals living in rocky reefs are identified as S. guamensis, while the reddish individuals living in coral reefs are identified as S. scaber; however, all individuals are the same species, S. guamensis. The true S. scaber is known only from two type specimens, collected off southeastern Australia (H. Motomura unpubl. data).

This species is commonly confused with Scorpaenodes guamensis or Scorpaenodes littoralis (Poss 1999).
Forms provisionally assigned to Apristurus sinensis from Australian waters are genetically distinct and may represent separate species (Last and Stevens 2009).

Previously two subspecies of Monochirus were recognized. Currently, Monochirus hispidus is considered endemic to the Mediterranean Sea and Monochirus atlanticus occurs from Portugal south to the Gulf of Guinea (Hoenywell et al. in review, Munroe pers comm. 2013).

The taxonomic status of the nominal species Cynoglossus arel and C. macrolepidotus remains uncertain. Menon (1977) and Munroe (2001) consider C. macrolepidotus a junior synonym of C. arel; however, other authors consider both to be valid species (e.g., Li and Wang 1995, Mishra et al. 1999). Cynoglossus macrolepidotus was recently included in the comparative material for the description of C. crepida (Fricke et al. 2017) and it is currently listed as valid in Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2020). Research is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of these two nominal species. For the purposes of this assessment, C. macrolepidotus will be considered to be a valid species.
Several taxonomic problems remain with the Pseudomonacanthus genus (Matsuura 2015).

Clark and Gohar (1953) described the Red Sea population as subspecies Brachaluteres baueri fahaqa and Hutchins and Swainston (1985) elevated it to a specific level, but still with taxonomic uncertainty due to the lack of specimens (Golani and Bogorodsky 2010).
This species has previously been classified as Cantherhines but is now considered to belong in the genus Thamnaconus (Motomura et al. 2017).
The literature suggests that this species may also occur off the coasts of Ecuador and Peru, but these records are unconfirmed and may have been misidentifications of another species.

The genus Apristurus contains at least 32 described species and a relatively large number of potentially undescribed ones. Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). The brunneus-group is characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length <6% total length (TL), 0.36 to 0.94 times in interorbital); 13 to 22 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows; a discontinuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Compagno (1984) considered it likely that the specimens and records of A. brunneus from the western North Pacific represent an assemblage of two or more brunneus-like species.

There are possible taxonomic problems in tropical latitudes (possible confusion with Zapteryx xyster), which may severely limit the functional range of  Z. exasperata (Ebert 2003).

Gonzalez Castro et al. (2008) found morphological and genetic differences between Mugil cephalus from the Mediterranean coast and M. liza/M. platanus from the Southwestern Atlantic coast. According to Fraga et al. (2007), M. liza and M. platanus should be treated as a single species or even subpopulations of M. cephalus. Heras et al. (2009) found that M. platanus and M. liza represent a continuum of a single species that is closely related to but distinct from M. cephalus, which itself appears to comprise a grouping of multiple and closely related species.

According to Menezes et al. (2010), only one species of lebranche mullet exists in the Caribbean Sea region and off the Atlantic coast of South America, with Mugil liza as the appropriate name. Considering the above, M. liza and M. platanus are considered the same species and the adopted name is M. liza. Mugil cephalus does not occur in the Southwestern Atlantic (Menezes et al. 2010).
Acanthopagrus randalli, a new sparid species, is described on the basis of two specimens, collected from Bahrain and Kuwait in the Arabian Gulf, respectively (Iwatsuki and Carpenter 2009).
This species can be misidentified with Pomadasys corvinaeformis.

The taxonomy of the genus Jenkinsia is in need of review (Whitehead 1985). This species may be a synonym of other species of Jenkinsia in the region, though it is possible that this is a valid species with a wider distribution. For the purposes of this assessment, Jenkinsia parvula is considered valid.

Some authors question the validity of this species and its taxonomic status need to be determined when a systematic revision is conducted (Whitehead et al. 1988, Nizinski and Munroe 2002). For the purposes of this assessment, Anchoviella blackburni will be treated as valid.
As observed during a re-examination of the type specimens of Ophioscion panamensis, it is suspected that this is a junior synonym of O. punctatissimus (L. Chao pers. comm. 2015).
The genus Gobiopterus is currently under revision and many species names are uncertain.
This species was re-described by Watson in 1995.

Kottelat (2013) pointed out that Euctenogobius striatus (from Madras, India) was a junior homonym of Awaous litturatus. The taxonomy of Awaous remains to be resolved. For the purposes of this assessment, A. litturatus is treated as endemic to the Philippines.It is also the type species of the genus Awaous.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. The holotype (unique) has not been examined since Koumans (1953). It has been listed as a synonym of Awaous melanocephalus (Koumans 1953; Maugé 1986), but Kottelat uses the name Awaous personatus (based on Ron Watson in litt.).
The genus Gobiopterus is currently under revision and many species names are uncertain.

The type specimen of Pseudapocryptes borneensis, collected from Banjarmasin, South Kalimantan, Indonesia, is lost (Murdy 1989). Yet a neotype was not designated because specimens from the type locality were unavailable, and the uncertainty of the identity of this species persisted (Murdy 1989). In a revision of the subfamily Oxudercinae, in which this species was included, Murdy (1989) considered individuals caught in Singapore as conspecifics but no recent records of this species are found in Singapore despite persistent efforts in searching for them (Larson et al. 2016). The most recent report of this species is in the mangrove forest of the Nakhon Si Thamarat province in Southern Thailand (Islam and Ikejima, 2010) but specimens are unavailable for identity confirmation.

Keith et al. (2015) synonymised Sicyopus cebuensis Chen and Shao, 1998 and Sicyopus exallisquamulus Watson & Kottelat 2006 under Sicyopus auxilimentus Watson & Kottelat 1994 without justifications for the decision.
This species may be a junior synonym of  Stiphodon atropurpureus, as recently collected specimens from the type locality of S. carisa could not be distinguished (Keith et al. 2015).
Maeda et al. (2015) synonymised Stiphodon aureorostrum Chen and Tan, 2005 under Stiphodon multisquamus Wu and Ni, 1986.
This species was re-described by Maeda and Tan (2013).
Its generic placement is unresolved (it does not belong in Oxyeleotris). Also it is likely that at least one more species has been confused under this name (Hoese D. pers. comm. 2018).
The current understanding of this species appears to be composed of several cryptic taxa, however the taxonomic work has not been undertaken (Z. Jaafar pers. comm. 2019).

This species is not listed in the Clupeidae catalouge (Whitehead 1985). Whether or not this is a valid species needs to be researched. It may be a senior synonym of another species of Herklotsichthys.
Known as Alosa brashnikovi in literature.

There is confusion regarding the taxonomic status of this species. This species was once considered a synonym of Alosa brashnikowii (Whitehead 1985) and has been considered a subspecies of A. brashnikowi (see Svetiovidov 1952). However, this species is currently considered to be valid as Alosa curensis (Suvorov 1907: Reshetnikov et al. 1997, Dorofeeva 1998, Esmaeili et al. 2014, Jouladeh-Roudbar et al. 2015) and will be treated as such for the purposes of this assessment.

The validity of this species has been contested by some studies after considering specimens as hybrids between different shad species (Reshetnikov et al. 1997). According to Coad (2017) and Berg (1948,1949), this is not a valid species.
The validity of this species has been questioned. It is possibly a synonym of Herklotsichthys castelnaui (Whitehead 1985).
The taxonomic validity of this species may need to be reviewed.
The type specimens of this species are reportedly lost and the taxonomy is uncertain (Nelson 1983, Whitehead et al. 1988).

Setipinna taty and S. tenuifilis can be easily confused, but the only species of Setipinna that occurs off China is S. tenuifilis (Whitehead et al. 1988, Young et al. 1994). Some authors identify S. taty as occurring in fisheries in the East China and Yellow seas (Sun et al. 2006) and Bohai Sea (Cheng and Zhou 1997, Tang et al.2003, Jin 2004); these records refer to S. tenuifilis (Whitehead et al. 1988, Young et al. 1994, Xu et al. 2014, H. Hata pers. comm. 2017).

Ilisha macrogaster is known from only two specimens, and the characters used to separate this species from I. filigera are slight differences in gill raker counts (Whitehead 1985). These two nominal species may be synonymous (Whitehead 1985).

Wongratana (1980) was only able to identify three specimens of this species, however, Whitehead (1985) considered that this species was probably distinct from other species. For the purposes of this assessment, we accept the preliminary conclusion of Whitehead (1985) that this is valid.
Ilisha striatula is caught with I. melastoma in Indian waters and may be subject to some misidentification with this species (Whitehead 1985, Coppola et al. 1994).

Genetic analyses indicate that this species is monophyletic with Epinephelus. However, a complete revision based on a combination of morphological and genetic data is required before a generic name change should be made.
Craig and Hastings (2007) consider the species Epinephelus caninus to be a member of the genus Mycteroperca.

Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) consider the species Epinephelus costae to be a member of genus Mycteroperca.
The name Epinephelus alexandrinus (Valenciennes 1828) was used for this species from 1895 to 1988, but this name is incorrect, as the holotype of Serranus alexandrinus Valenciennes is a specimen of Epinephelus fasciatus, a known species from the Red Sea and Indo-Pacific area.

Epinephelus quinquefasciatus was previously considered E. itajara, but is now considered a separate species, with E. itajara only in the Atlantic and E. qinquefasciatus in the Pacific (Craig et al. 2009).
This species has been and still is frequently confused with Epinephelus coioides and possibly E. malabaricus as well (M. Craig and Y. Sadovy pers. comm. 2018).
This species is very similar to Epinephelus flavocaeruleus, but differs notably in colour. It may represent a Western Australian subspecies of E. flavocaeruleus (Heemstra and Randall 1993).
A recent publication changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007) and a change of family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).
A recent publication changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007) and the family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).
This species is easily confused with Hyporthodus octofasciatus, which has likely led to many cases of misidentification (M. Craig pers. comm. 2018).

Heemstra and Randall (1993) described the morphological differences between Mycteroperca prionura, M. jordani and M. xenarcha. Mycteroperca prionura can easily be confused with Epinephelus analogus, which it closely resembles in colour.

References to H. whitei off the east coast of Africa should be H. camelopardalis. Genetic data indicate that this species is distinct from H. whitei in Australia (S. Casey in litt. to Lourie et al. 1999).

Two sub-species of Engraulis mordax have been recognized based on small anatomical differences, mainly in body depth, head length number of vertebrae and maximum standard length: Engraulis mordax mordax known from British Columbia to Baja California and E. mordax nanus found in the bays of California (Hubbs 1925, Hildebrand 1943, Whitehead et al. 1988). Three subpopulations are currently recognized (McHugh 1951) based on evidence from morphometric characters (Spratt 1972), protein variation (Vrooman and Palmoa 1975, Vrooman et al. 1981, Diaz-Jaimes et al. 1999) and genetic data (LeComte et al. 2004, Lewis and Lema 2019): the northern subpopulation distributed in waters off British Columbia to northern California; the central subpopulation extending from San Francisco Bay to Central Baja California in the southern California Current Ecosystem (CCE); and the southern subpopulation distributed from central to southern Baja California and into the Gulf of California (Sydeman et al. 2020).
Conger marginatus was removed from synonymy with Conger cinereus by Randall (2005, 2007).

This species has long been known as Conger wilsoni (Bloch and Schneider 1801), applied to specimens from throughout the Indo-Pacific. However, the species as described by Bloch and Schneider is unidentifiable. The oldest available name that unequivocally refers to this species is Leptocephalus monganius Phillipps, 1932 (Smith and Stewart 2015).
This species was recently assigned to the genus Bathycongrus (Smith and Ho 2018).

The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The Dwarf Black Stingray (Hemitrygon parvonigra) was referred to as Dasyatis sp. A in Last and Stevens (1994) before being described as a new species by Last and White (2008).

Last et al. (2016) note that the placement of Megatrygon microps in the family Dasyatidae is provisional; it may be more closely related to the freshwater Neotropical stingrays (Potamotrygonidae) of South America. Further investigations are needed to determine the position of this species in the order Myliobatiformes, but it may belong in its own family (Last et al. 2016).
The taxonomic status and validity of this species is uncertain. The only known specimen (which may be lost) may have actually been an Apristurus species.
Although only recently described (Carvalho et al. 2002), the Bigeye Electric Ray (Narcine oculifera) is distinctive and is not easily confused with any other electric rays.

The female holotype of the Pita Skate was comprehensively examined in a recent taxonomic assessment of Okamajei (Weigmann et al. 2015). This showed unequivocally that the Pita Skate does not belong to the genus Okamejei, but instead to either Leucoraja or Rajella. This is evidenced by its overall appearance, particularly the absence of dark-marked ventral pores (vs. dark marked ventral pores present in Okamejei), a rather short and thick tail (vs. a long and slender tail), a very short interdorsal space (vs. a wide interdorsal space), and a short postdorsal tail section (vs. a long postdorsal tail section). Due to the lack of an adult male specimen and the accordingly unknown clasper characters, the Pita Skate specimen cannot definitely be assigned to a genus and for the time being should be placed as incertae sedis in the general genus Raja Linnaeus. More specimens are urgently needed (Weigmann et al. 2015).

This species is likely closely related to Hippocampus kuda and H. mohnikei. Further research is needed to identify the full extent of its range and how it overlaps with those of H. kuda and H. mohnikei (Zhang et al. 2016).
The single paratype for this species was described as a new species, Bellottia galatheae (Nielsen and Møller 2008).

The genus Hapalogenys has been traditionally placed in the family Haemulidae (Akazaki 1984, McKay 2001 and Nelson 2006). A new family name, Hapalogeniidae (Springer and Raasch 1995) was established; however, this was not based on strong supporting evidence. Furthermore, Hapalogenys has been reported to be close to the family Dinopercidae and may belong to a group of ‘Lobotes-like’ species. There is a need for further study on the familial position of Hapalogenys (Iwatsuki and Russell 2006).

The validity of this species is questionable as the holotype is a small specimen (~7 cm) that still shows juvenile characteristics, and this species may be conspecific with one of the other species in the area (McGrouther 1999).
The taxonomic validity of this species is questionable. It is not recognized by Paxton and Hulley (1999) and its status has not been evaluated (Eschmeyer et al. 2017).

Various authors ascribe the name Dunckerocampus to either a separate genus (Kuiter 2000, 2009) or as a subgenus of Doryrhamphus (Dawson 1985). Dunckerocampus is treated here as a separate genus based on observable morphological differences, including the absence of brood pouch folds on pregnant males.

Osterhage et al. (2016) have described a new species of seamoth (Pegasus tetrabelos) that is sympatric with P. volitans in the Torres Strait and Great Barrier Reef. They also designated a lectotype for P. volitans.
Dawson (1984) and most later authors consider Idiotropiscis to be a subgenus of Acentronura.
It is currently not clear whether Hephthocara crassiceps and Hephthocara simum are separate species or conspecific.
Paraliparis copei consists of three subspecies: Paraliparis copei copei, P. c. wilsoni and P. c. kerguelensis.
There remains some taxonomic debate surrounding the species status of Merluccius hernandezi (Lloris et al. 2003).  It was previously classed as belonging to the species M. angustimanus.
Dactylanthias aplodactylus is only known from a single specimen.

Kuiter (2009) suggested that M. brevicorpus may in fact be a synonym of M. pygmaeus, which he considered a full species as opposed to Dawson's (1985) assignment to subspecies status - M. b. pygmaeus. The specimens for all of the aforementioned species show only minor differences in meristic counts (Dawson 1985, Fricke 2004). Further taxonomic research and DNA analyses are needed to understand the diversity of this genus, especially in New Caledonia.

Pseudophallus brasiliensis Dawson 1974 is a junior synonym of P. mindii. Dawson (1974) originally described P. brasiliensis based on low meristic counts in Brazil compared to the previously described P. mindii. Later research revealed similar or lower counts in other parts of the range of P. mindii, indicating that the two are one and the same (Dawson 1982). From Dawson (1982): "Specimens with low counts from the Amazon drainage were described as P. brasiliensis, but samples with similar or lower counts have subsequently been examined from the Orinoco River and Lake Izabal, Guatemala. In the apparent absence of consistent differences in coloration or other morphological features, these specimens are considered to represent local populations of P. mindii wherein low meristic values result from unknown environmental influences."
The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015).

The correct taxonomic authority for this species requires clarification.

Somniosus longus from the Pacific Ocean has long been considered a synonym of S. rostratus from the Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea (Compagno 1984, Francis et al. 1988, Compagno 1999). Yano et al. (2004) resurrected S. longus on the basis of several morphological and meristic characters. However their sample sizes of S. longus and S. rostratus were too small to properly define the range of variation in these characters, so their conclusion needs verification using larger sample sizes and preferably DNA analyses. Nevertheless, S. longus has been considered valid by recent authors (Ebert et al. 2013).

Brochiraja aenigma remains poorly defined. A recent trawl survey to the type locality provided no additional specimens. Hence, its generic placement is provisional because features of adult males are unknown, and the only known female lacks a rostral thorn and is in a poor state of preservation. Within the southwest Pacific it is unique in appearance having a rounded disc covered in very fine granular denticles, a very long tail, and high meristic values (Last and McEachran 2006).
The Broken Ridge Skate (Notoraja lira) is a recently described species (McEachran and Last 2008).

The Sapphire Skate (Notoraja sapphira) was first documented in 1996, when a single specimen was collected on the Norfolk Ridge, and thought to be a member of the genus Pavoraja (Séret in Grandperrin et al. 1997). In 2006, four more specimens were collected, and it was determined that the specimens were all part of the genus Notoraja (Last and Séret in Anonymous 2006). The Sapphire Skate was described from these five specimens, and comparison with its closest congener, Blue Skate (N. azurea), found the two species to be distinct.

Scymnodon plunketi may be a junior synonym of Centroscymnus macracanthus (White et al. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is required.

Scott (1983) recognized T. arawatae as a senior synonym of T. jacksonensis, while Heemstra and Kannemeyer (1984) recognized T. arawatae as a junior synonym of T. trachypterus (Martin 2015, Roberts et al. 2015).

Laeops natalensis Norman 1931 was described based on two specimens collected off KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. No additional specimens have been reported to date. Voronina et al. (2020), in the most recent revision of the genus Laeops, considered L. sinusarabici from the Red Sea to be the junior subjective synonym of Laeops natalensis Norman 1931. However, several morphological differences (albeit small) were noted between the holotype of L. natalensis from off South Africa and specimens (including types) of L. sinusarabici from the Red Sea. Given the large geographic distance between capture sites of these nominal species, the difference in the depths of capture, and the fact that the Red Sea is a renowned area of endemism for fishes, both nominal species are treated herein as valid and separate conservation assessments are required.

Laeops sinusarabici Chabaunaud 1968 was described based on specimens collected in the Red Sea. This nominal species was synonymized with Grammatobothus krempfi Chabanaud 1929 by Desoutter et al. (2001) without detailed comment regarding this decision. Later authors (e.g., Bogorodsky et al. 2014, Bogorodsky and Randall 2018, Golani and Fricke 2018) considered L. sinusarabici to be a valid species, endemic to the Red Sea.

In the most recent revision of the genus Laeops, Voronina et al. (2020) considered L. sinusarabici to be the junior subjective synonym of Laeops natalensis Norman 1931 from off South Africa. However, several morphological differences (albeit small) were noted between the holotype of L. natalensis from off South Africa and specimens (including types) of L. sinusarabici from the Red Sea. Given the large geographic distance between capture sites of these nominal species, the difference in the depths of capture, and the fact that the Red Sea is a renowned area of endemism for fishes, both nominal species are treated herein as valid and separate conservation assessments are required.

According to Hoshino (2001), the citharid genus Paracitharus Regan 1920 is sometimes mistaken as the synonym of Citharoides Hubbs 1915 (e.g. Chapleau 1993). He reports that this idea can be traced back to Norman (1934), who synonymized C. macrolepidotus Hubbs 1915 with Arnoglossus macrolepis Gilchrist 1904, which was later transferred to Paracitharus. Norman (1934) applied the name Citharoides macrolepis (Gilchrist 1904) as the senior synonym. 

Hubbs (1945) recognized both species and genera as valid based on differences in the canal shape on their posterior lateral line scales. Hoshino (2001) confirmed these observations and concluded that it was incorrect to synonymize Paracitharus with Citharoides. However, this systematic decision has not been accepted by all subsequent authors (e.g. Choi et al. 2003, Hoese and Bray 2006, Fricke et al. 2018). Following the morphological data presented in Hubbs (1945) and Hoshino (2001), Paracitharus is herein recognized as a valid genus, distinct from Citharoides, with its type species, P. macrolepis (Gilchrist 1904).

This species is sometimes referred to in the literature as Cynoglossus ecaudatus (e.g., Menon 1977, Yokogawa et al. 2008). Cynoglossus natalensis, described from off Natal, South Africa, is considered a junior subjective synonym of C. acaudatus by Menon (1977). Cynoglossus hunteri, described from Point Vermetha, Mozambique, was also placed in synonymy of C. acaudatus by Menon (1977).
There is some confusion between Cynoglossus semifasciatus and C. macrostomus (R. Nair pers. comm. 2019).

Symphurus microrhynchus was described based on a single specimen collected in the Java Sea at a depth of 82 m (Weber 1913). A second specimen was taken off Indonesia (Koumans 1953). Munroe and Marsh (1997) redescribed S. microrhynchus based on 11 specimens collected at different localities ranging from Tanzania to French Polynesia, including the holotype of S. holothuriae, which they considered to be a junior subjective synonym of S. microrhynchus. Subsequent study (Lee and Munroe unpublished data) re-examined these specimens and discovered that actually seven different species were represented in the material, including S. microrhynchus, S. holothuriae and five undescribed species. Lee and Munroe (unpublished data) provide a redescription of S. microrhynchus and limited the known material of this species to the holotype and the specimen mentioned in Koumans (1953).

Western Indian Ocean reports of Achirus pavoninus are actually records of Pardachirus morrowi (Randall and Johnson 2007).

Cantor (1849) considered Brachirus Swainson 1839 to be preoccupied by Brachyrus Swainson 1838 and proposed the replacement name Synaptura. Subsequently, Brachirus Swainson was determined to be a valid genus name (Jordan 1923). Bleeker (1875) distinguished Brachirus Swainson from Synaptura, but did not designate a type species. Later, Chabanaud (1928) restricted the name Synaptura to accommodate four nominal species of elongate soles, Synaptura albomaculata Kaup 1858, Pleuronectes commersonnii Lacepede 1802, S. lusitanica Brito Capello 1868, and S. marginata Boulenger 1900. 


Desoutter et al. (2001) commented that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not a valid genus name. In a revision of members of the genus Synaptura sensu Chabanaud, Vachon et al. (2007) also stated that Synaptura sensu Chabanaud was not valid. Based on the results of their study, the five nominal species (including Synaptura cadenati Chabanaud 1948) formally placed in Synaptura sensu Chabanaud were found to be closely related to Dagetichthys lakdoensis Stauch and Blanc 1964 and they transferred these species to Dagetichthys. This decision is followed herein.

The taxonomic status of this species and Zebrias annularis needs to be investigated (T. Munroe and R. Nair pers. comm. 2019). At present, both nominal species are considered valid (Fricke et al. 2019).

Specimens from off Somalia formerly identified as this species are in fact of the newly described Vivaldi's Catshark (Bythaelurus vivaldii) (Weigmann and Kaschner 2017). A specimen from off northern Tanzania formerly identified as this species is in fact of the newly described Narrowhead Catshark (Bythaelurus tenuicephalus) (Kaschner et al. 2015).

The holotype and only known specimen of Urobatis marmoratus is missing and the species is unrecognizable from the drawing in the original description (which is from 1892). The species was not treated in Last et al. (2016) but is considered valid by Fricke (2020). Additional specimens are required to confirm its validity.

When first redescribed, Urolophus armatus was considered to possibly represent a new genus (Séret and Last 2003). A new genus, Spinilophus, has since been erected for this species as it was unique among the Urolophus in having dorsal denticles and thorns with all other Urolophus devoid of squamation (Yearsley and Last 2016).
The West African Catshark has been previously confused with the Nursehound (Scyliorhinus stellaris), which has a more northern distribution.
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into synonymy with Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908.
This species has been confused with the Polkadot Skate (Dipturus chinensis) in recent literature (Last et al. 2016a).

A species of Amblyraja, previously identified as A. cf. georgiana, occurs around the Falkland Islands (Malvinas) and appears to be most closely related to A. frerichsi. It does however, differ from A. frerichsi in a number of characteristics and may be identical to an undescribed Amblyraja from South Georgia (as specified in Endicott et al. 2002) (J. Pompert pers. comm. 2019). Amblyraja georgiana from the Ross Sea appears to have low-level genetic differentiation from South Atlantic A. georgiana, and further work is required to determine whether the Ross Sea A. georgiana is distinct (M. Francis pers. comm. 2019). Taxonomic resolution of this issue is ongoing. Endicott et al. (2002) found A. georgiana to have a restricted depth range around South Georgia, with an unknown rajid species comprising the rest of the deep water captures. Although A. georgiana is reported to have been regularly caught around Antarctica in deep water, findings by Endicott et al. (2002) suggest that complications and difficulties in identification of Antarctic rajids may lead to misidentification.

This species has been relocated from the genus Okamejei to Orbiraja (Last et al. 2016). The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. Orbiraja philipi has been considered a possible synonym of Orbiraja powelli Alcock 1898 by Séret (1989) and further specimens are needed to determine its validity (Last et al. 2016).

Holohalaelurus grennian was originally included within H. melanostigma (Norman, 1939), was then synonymized with H. punctatus (Bass et al. 1975), and in recent years was included in the East African Holohalaelurus species-complex (Compagno 1988). However, H. grennian is clearly distinct from all other Holohalaelurus taxa (Human 2006).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

The specimen from off Tanzania identified as Cruriraja andamanica by McEachran and Fechhelm (1982) was found to be well-separated (i.e. the ordination of principle components with respect to its morphometric vectors fell outside the 90% confidence ellipse area) from the holotype and other specimens (Vinu et al. 2017). These authors conclude that this Tanzanian specimen is questionable and should be thoroughly re-evaluated to determine whether it might represent a separate species that has yet to be described.

Dipturus wuhanlingi was described in 2008 (Jeong and Nakabo 2008). Among the Dipturus species distributed in the western North Pacific (i.e., Dipturus gigas, D. kwangtungensis, D. macrocauda, D. tengu, and D. wuhanlingi) this species has the unique character of a continuous row of mid-dorsal thorns from nape to the tail distinguishing it from other regional Dipturus spp. The validity of this species is not doubtful.
Squalus mahia is a recently described Squalus of the megalops-cubensis group (Viana et al. 2018).

The species name is not addressed in Ebert et al. (2013), however, C. caerulopunctatum is considered to be distinct from C. plagiosum and thus a valid species (W. White pers. comm. cited in Weigmann 2016).

Micropogonias manni may be a junior synonym of M. furnieri (Kong and Valdés 1990). The latter occurs in the southwest Atlantic from Cuba to northern Argentina. Micropogonias manni is endemic to the Araucanía Region of Chile but the taxonomy of this species requires further study (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2020).

Squalus bahiensis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. The taxonomic description includes mostly specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei and S. mitsukurii, and fewer specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. fernandinus.
Squalus lobularis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).

Squalus quasimodo is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei, S. fernandinus, S. lebruni, and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).

Commerson's original specimen from Fort Dauphin, Madagascar and his description of the species were lost (Cuvier and Valenciennes, 1830 - in: Griffiths and Heemstra (1995)). Following examination of Argyrosomus specimens from several countries, including Madagascar, Griffiths and Heemstra (1995) designated a neotype of A. hololepidotus to resolve some of the taxonomic confusion in this genus.
This species closely resembles Diaphus coeruleus and D. lucidus (Gjøsaeter 1989), and has not been reported since its first description.

This species was originally described as distinct from Tarletonbeania crenularis by Eigenmann and Eigenmann in 1890. Gilbert (1915) reports that original described differences between T. tenua and T. crenularis are due to the poor condition of the original specimens and that T. tenua and T. crenularis are not significantly different. Parr (1929) accepted Gilbert’s opinion on this and also T. tenua as a junior synonym of T. crenularis. Kobayashi (1958) refers to T. tenua as a junior synonym of T. crenularis. In summary, it is doubtful that T. tenua is a valid species.
This species is a synonym of Cynoscion parvipinnis (Chao et al. 1995, Chao 2002).
The type specimens were probably lost in a Tsunami in Valparaíso in 1962. There is some uncertainty about the taxonomic validity of this species (Kong and Valés 1990).

According to Walker and Radford (1992), there have been many instances where Eastern Pacific species have been ascribed to Umbrina (e.g., U. imberbis = Sciaena, probably callaensis). However, current taxonomic authority databases continue to use the name Umbrina imberbis.

Umbrina robinsoni Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908 was considered a junior synonym of Umbina ronchus (Chao and Trewavas 1990), however the former is a valid species distributed from South Africa to Oman (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Umbrina ronchus is often reported from the northwest Indian Ocean, but specimens from there are U. robinsoni.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.

Stolephorus continentalis was recently described based on 36 specimens collected off Hong Kong and northern Vietnam (Hata and Motomura 2018). It is morphologically similar to the congener S. chinensis.

This species was previously described as Stolephorus insularis oceanicus by Hardenburg (1933). Recently, it was tentatively elevated to the species level by Hata and Motomura (2018) as Stolephorus oceanicus. Detailed taxonomic studies are needed and in progress. For the purposes of the assessment, S. oceanicus will be treated as a valid species.

There is some disagreement on the validity of this species. Pseudoscopelus australis was described by Prokofiev and Kukuev (2008) on the basis of a single specimen from Antarctica (specific locality information unavailable) but later synonymized with P. australis by Melo (2010). Chelon dumerili is the only species of Liza whose distribution extends from the tropical Atlantic Ocean, around the Cape, to the Indian Ocean coast of Africa. Some authors have suggested that geographically distant populations should be recognised as different subspecies. Delais (1954), studying mullets from Mauritania and Senegal, recognized two subspecies: C. saliens dumerili from the north with 37-42 (mode 40) scales in longitudinal series, and C. saliens hoefleri in the south with 33-42 (mode 36) scales. However, scale counts for specimens from different regions of West Africa might not be as clearly demarked as Delais (1954) suggested and there is insufficient evidence of a subspecific distinction between dumerili and hoefleri. Trewavas and Ingham (1972) recognized two subspecies of Chelon dumerili: C. d. dumerili characterized by 37-41 gill rakers and distributed from Senegal to the Niger river; and C. d. canaliculatus characterized by 45-55 gill rakers and distributed from the Congo river to Mozambique. However, the diagnostic difference in raker numbers is not consistent for all specimens examined from the western and southern ranges. Some variation has been detected in pharyngobranchial organ morphology for C. dumerili, but this variation is not sufficient to define separate species or subspecies. Further analyses are in progress.

There is some uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of this species (Ozawa et al. 1990). This species is part of the Diplophos taenia-complex, and requires further revision (A. Harold pers. comm. 2019).

Echiodon anchipterus has been considered a junior synonym of this species (E. coheni) in past literature (Markle and Olney 1990, Nielsen et al. 1999). However, according to Williams and Machida (1992), E. anchipterus is a valid species separate from E. coheni.

This species was described with no type specimen and locality, but it has been presumed to be from the Arabian Gulf (Wallace 1967, Compagno 1986, Carvalho et al. 2002). It is considered to be one of the most widely distributed electric rays of the Western Indian Ocean (Carvalho et al. 2002, Last et al. 2016). However, the status of this species is uncertain as it is possibly a species-complex (Last et al. 2016). It is highly variable and confused with the Panther Torpedo (Torpedo panthera) (Last et al. 2016). The present account is therefore provisional, and in the event that species within the complex are better delineated, reassessment will be required (this may result in the status of electric rays being revised upwards, on the basis of small populations with localized distributions).

This species is genetically and morphologically similar to Siganus vulpinus, but differs in coloration (Nanami 2015). Species of the family Siganidae are known for their morphological uniformity, therefore, for some authors, the colour has been enough to consider both species valid; while for others, S. unimaculatus is only a color variety of S. vulpinus. Further studies are necessary to understand its taxonomic status (Gawel and Woodland 1974, Kuriiwa et al. 2007). It has also been suggested that two sub-genera exist within Siganus: Siganus and Lo, with this species belonging to the latter. Borsa and colleagues (2007) have suggested that this division does not exist and all species should be considered as Siganus.
