Plectorhinchus griseus was previously treated as a junior synonym of P. schotaf; however, it has been confirmed as a valid species due to the distinguishing characters of body depth and dorsal-fin ray count (Johnson and Wilmer 2015).

Pseudoscopelus cephalus is included in the P. scriptus species-groups along with P. cordilluminatus, P. obtusifrons, P. pierbartus, P. sagamianus and P. scriptus (Melo 2010). Recent reviews affirmed it is a valid species and have not identified further specimens beyond the holotype.

This species was recently split from Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) (Song et al. 2017). Atractoscion atelodus Song, Kim & Kang 2017 is endemic to the eastern coasts of Australia while Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) occurs off South Africa. Therefore, literature referring to A. aequidens (Cuvier 1830) off Australia is actually A. atelodus Song, Kim & Kang 2017.

This species was recently split from Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) (Song et al. 2017). Atractoscion microlepis Song, Kim & Kang 2017 is known from Oman while Atractoscion aequidens (Cuvier 1830) occurs off South Africa. Therefore, literature referring to A. aequidens (Cuvier 1830) from the Arabian Sea is likely to be A. microlepis Song, Kim & Kang 2017.

Chabanaud (1928) described this nominal species on the basis of about 11 specimens taken from Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. In an unpublished dissertation, Ramos (1998) indicated that Catathyridium grandirivi is a junior, subjective synonym of C. garmani. This opinion has not been recognized by subsequent authors (e.g. Desoutter et al. 2001, Fricke et al. 2021). For the purposes of this assessment, C. grandirivi is treated as a valid species. Further work is needed to determine the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

Historically, the genetic level placement of this species has been confused in the literature. Currently, it is placed in the genus Anchoa (Miller 1945). However, in more recent taxonomic reviews of engraulids (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Loeb et al. 2018) this species seems to be more appropriately placed within the genus Anchoviella. As this species is currently considered to be valid as Anchoa analis in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018), for the purposes of this assessment, Anchoa analis will be used as the valid species name.

Separation of S. aurita from S. brasiliensis based on gill raker shape is tentative (Whitehead 1985). Sardinella brasiliensis may be a junior synonym of S. aurita (Whitehead 1985).  Purported differences in gill raker morphology between these two nominal species need to be confirmed.  More study is needed to evaluate the morphological and genetic differences between and among these populations in order to determine their taxonomic status (Whitehead 1985, Munroe 2002). Recent studies based on molecular data indicate that S. brasiliensis is a junior synonym of S. aurita (Mabragana et al. 2011, Stern et al. 2017) but this species is still recognized as valid (Eschmeyer et al. 2017). Sardinella janeiro (Eigenmann, 1894) has been erroneously applied for Sardinella brasiliensis in some older publications (Figueiredo et al. 2010). For the purposes of this assessment, Sardinella brasiliensis will be treated as valid.
Hybridization has occurred between N. come and N. japonica at Okinawa (Imai et al. 2009, Uehara et al. 2009).

Some confusion has existed regarding the geographical distribution of Sardinella jussieu because some authors placed S. dayi, which is known from southern India and Sri Lanka, into the synonymy of this species. Currently, both species are regarded as valid.  
Sardinella dayi was described from Karwar, India, and S. jussieu was described from Mauritius. Wongratana (1980) recognized both as valid species. Subsequently, S. dayi was considered a junior subjective synonym of S. jussieu (Whitehead 1985). More recently, S. dayi has been recognized as a valid species (e.g., Bijukumar and Sushama 2000, Mishra and Krishnan 2003). This hypothesis is also supported by the conclusions of Hata (pers. comm. 2018). Therefore, for purposes of this assessment, specimens collected off southern India and Sri Lanka are considered to be S. dayi. Specimens collected at insular localities in the southwestern Indian Ocean (Reunion, Mauritius, and Madagascar) are considered to be Sardinella jussieu.
Records of this species from India may refer to the similar Thryssa kammalensoides (Whitehead et al. 1988).

Whitehead et al. (1988) report taxonomic confusion regarding identifications of this species. They note that perhaps all records since description of the species have been either compilations or misidentifications.

Confusion exists regarding the taxonomic status and geographical distribution of Sardinella dayi. Sardinella dayi was described from Karwar, India, and S. jussieu was described from Mauritius. Wongratana (1980) recognized both as valid species. Subsequently, S. dayi was considered a junior subjective synonym of S. jussieu (Whitehead 1985). More recently, S. dayi has been recognized as a valid species (e.g., Bijukumar and Sushama 2000, Mishra and Krishnan 2003). This hypothesis is also supported by the conclusions of Hata (pers. comm. 2018). Therefore, for purposes of this assessment, specimens collected off southern India and Sri Lanka are considered to be S. dayi. Specimens collected at insular localities in the southwestern Indian Ocean (Reunion, Mauritius, and Madagascar) are considered to be Sardinella jussieu.
This species was recently separated from Etrumeus sadina (Dibattista et al. 2012) which was previously recognized as E. teres by Whitehead (1985).

This species was recently recognized as a species separated from E. sadina and E. whiteheadi off the coast of eastern Africa (DiBattista et al. 2012) which was previously recognized as E. teres by Whitehead (1985). This species is very similar to E. golanii (DiBattista et al. 2012). E. wongratanai can be easily separated from E. sadina based on vertebral counts (52-53 vs. 49, respectively: DiBattista et al. 2012).

This nominal species has previously been considered a junior synonym of Arnoglossus muelleri (Gomon et al. 1994) and its status remains questionable (KA pers. comm. 2019). More research is needed to determine the validity of this species.

The generic placement of this species is uncertain (K. Amaoka pers. comm. 2019). It was originally described in the genus Paralichthys (Steindachner 1898) but was later placed in Arnoglossus (Pequeno and Lamilla 2000).
Arnoglossus kotthausi was designated as a replacement name for Arnoglossus profundus Kotthaus 1977 (Klausewitz and Schneider 1986).
The status of this recently-described species is uncertain (K. Amaoka pers. comm. 2019).

This species is regarded as valid by some authors; however, others consider it to be a synonym of Bothus maculiferus (Poey 1860) (Munroe 2002). Poey (1860) described Bothus ellipticus and Bothus maculiferus in the same publication and identified them as separate species.

The taxonomic status of this nominal species is uncertain. D. Hensley considered Bothus tricirrhitus a synonym of B. pantherinus (in litt., Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003), but no formal taxonomic revision has been published.
The status of this recently-described species, known only from the type series, is uncertain. More research is needed to verify the validity of this nominal species (K. Amaoka pers. comm. 2019).

This species was originally described as Asterorhombus osculus Amaoka and Arai 1998, and later transferred to Engyprosopon, when the genus Asterorhombus was redefined (Hensley and Randall 2003, Hensley 2005).

The validity of Grammatobothus krempfi Chabanaud 1929 is questionable. This nominal species was described on the basis of a single specimen taken in the South China Sea off Con Son Island, southeastern Viet Nam (Chabanaud 1929). This appears to be the only record for this species for which there is a voucher specimen. Records from Taiwan (Shen 1983, 1993; Li and Wang 1995; Hensley and Amaoka 2001; Shao et al. 2008; Shen and Wu 2012) are questionable, because at least one is based on a misidentification and for the other records, no voucher specimens exist to verify the identifications of these specimens (Amaoka and Ho 2019). Further specimens are needed to validate the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

This nominal species was described from a single specimen collected pelagically in the Gulf of Panama (Bruun 1937). Evseenko (1999) considered it to be a junior subjective synonym of Monolene maculipinna; however, Amaoka and Imamura (2000) consider it a valid species. Further work is needed to clarify the status of this nominal species.

The taxonomic status of this nominal species remains uncertain. Bogorodsky and Randall (2018) considered this species to be a junior synonym of Bothus pantherinus (Rüppell 1830) while Golani and Fricke (2018) and Fricke et al. (2019) consider it a valid species. Further research is needed to determine the status of this species.

There is controversy whether this species is a valid species or an ecomorph of E. encrasicolus (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2013).  Since the species was first described in 2004 based on its genetic and morphological distinctness from sympatric E. encrasicolus, new surveys have confirmed its validity. The new data include a nuclear DNA study by Bouchenak-Khelladi et al. (2008) which revealed a complex of three species in the northeastern Atlantic and Mediterranean region (namely, E. encrasicolus, E. albidus, and a third anchovy species from the Canary islands and Alboran Sea); a nuclear-DNA and morphometric study by Karahan et al. 2014) which reported E. albidus from southern Turkey and distinguished it from the pelagic species occurring there (E. cf encrasicolus).

There are clearly two ecomorphs, but the morphological and habitat differences correspond to clearcut genetic differences at nuclear loci (Borsa 2002; Borsa et al. 2004; Bouchenak-Khelladi et al. 2008; Karahan et al. 2014; Le Moan et al. 2016). However, it is currently considered a valid species in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018). For the purposes of this assessment, Engraulis albidus is considered a valid species distributed in coastal waters of the northern Mediterranean Sea.

Menon (1977) considered Cynoglossus semilaevis Günther 1873 as the senior synonym of C. rhomaleus (Jordan and Starks 1906) and C. roulei Wu 1932. Although Li and Wang (1995) considered C. roulei to be a valid species, it is treated here as a junior synonym of C. semilaevis.

This species has long been considered to be a synonym of Cynoglossus kopsii (Bleeker 1851) by some authors (e.g., Norman 1928, Menon 1977, Shen et al. 1993, Shen and Wu 2011). Wang et al. (2016) and Lee (2019) considered Cynoglossus brachycephalus to be a valid species. Currently, it is considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2020); however, further work is needed to clarify the status of this nominal species.

Menon (1977) considered this species to be a junior synonym of Cynoglossus dollfusi; however, this hypothesis is not supported by the data. Despite the two species being currently considered distinct, more specimens are needed for a better understanding of the taxon (Munroe 2017). Furthermore, Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) reported C. lingua from the Red Sea based on the specimen that Chabanaud (1949) later designated as the holotype of C. cleopatridis. These two species are currently considered to be valid species (Munroe 2017).

This species was originally described by Chabanaud (1931) as Paraplagusia dollfusi based on a single specimen. Shortly after, Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) placed P. dollfusi in the genus Cynoglossus as Cynoglossus (Trulla) dollfusi (Munroe and Kong 2016). However, when Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) transferred this species to Cynoglossus, the designation was not explicit, leading several subsequent authors to believe that Gruvel and Chabanaud (1937) had described a new species (see Munroe and Kong 2016, Munroe 2017 for history). Uncertainty was further aggravated by the apparent loss of the only two known specimens. Extensive analysis of the taxonomic history of this species, as well as the location of the two long lost known specimens, has confirmed that Paraplagusia dollfusi and Cynoglossus (Trulla) dollfusi referred to the same species, now valid as Cynoglossus dollfusi (Munroe 2017). Furthermore, C. dollfusi had been proposed to be a senior synonym of C. cleopatridis (Menon 1977). The two specimens of C. dollfusi were misidentified as C. sealarki by Chabanaud (1947, 1954), and thus C. dollfusi was treated as a junior subjective synonym of C. sealarki. Recently, Munroe (2017) determined that these two misidentified specimens were actually the holotype and the second known specimen of C. dollfusi. Cynoglossus dollfusi is a valid species distinct from C. sealarki and C. cleopatridis (Munroe and Kong 2016, Munroe 2017).

There has been confusion regarding the validity of this nominal species. Menon (1977) considered it to be a junior subjective synonym of Cynoglossus capensis, though he noted several characters to distinguish the nominal species. Barnard (1925) also noted differences in characters of specimens that he identified as Trulla microphthalmus compared to those of C. capensis, however, he did not consider these differences to be significant enough to recognize two species. Further study based on additional material is needed to resolve this taxonomic question (T. Munroe unpublished data). Munroe (unpublished data) considers the morphological differences sufficient to recognize both as valid species.

This nominal species was originally described based on a single specimen (36.5 cm total length) as Plagusia oligolepis Bleeker 1855 from Java, Indonesia. Norman (1928) considered Cynoglossus oligolepis as a junior synonym of C. macrolepidotus (Bleeker). Menon (1977) considered both C. macrolepidotus and C. oligolepis as junior synonyms of C. arel. Li and Wang (1995) considered both C. oligolepis and C. arel as valid species, and it was included in the comparative material for the description of C. crepida (Fricke et al. 2017). 

Given the confusion, the taxonomic status of this nominal species remains uncertain. More work is needed to establish the validity of this nominal species. Erring on the side that this species is valid, we provide an assessment using information only on this species and not that of proposed senior synonyms.

This nominal species was described on the basis of two specimens, which are apparently lost. Features overlap those of two other species of Cynoglossus from the Red Sea, so the taxonomic status of C. pottii is uncertain (Bogorodsky and Randall 2019, T. Munroe pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Cynoglossus brachycephalus (Norman 1928) and C. kopsii (Menon 1977) but was recently treated as valid (Wang et al. 2016).

Regan (1905) described Cynoglossus purpureomaculatus on the basis of a single specimen from the Inland Sea of Japan. Matsubara (1955) and Ochiai (1963) consider C. purpureomaculatus Regan a junior synonym of C. trigrammus. Menon (1977) considered both C. purpureomaculatus and C. trigrammus as junior synonyms of C. abbreviatus. Lindberg and Fedorov (1993) also consider C. purpureomaculatus a junior synonym of C. abbreviatus. 

However, later authors, e.g., Li and Wang (1995) and Kottelat (2001, 2013), consider C. purpureomaculatus to be a valid species. These authors (Li and Wang 1995; Kottelat 2001, 2013) also placed Cynoglossus pellegrini Wu 1932 in the synonymy of C. purpureomaculatus. Chevey and Lemasson (1937) reported Cynoglossus pellegrini from the Gulf of Tonkin.  
Available evidence (Li and Wang 1995; Kottelat 2001, 2013) as well as that contained in Chevey and Lemasson (1937; according to Kottelat 2001), supports recognition of C. purpureomaculatus as a valid species.

Chabanaud (1947) misidentified two specimens of Cynoglossus dollfusi as C. sealarki. Recently, Munroe (2017) determined that these two misidentified specimens were actually the holotype and the second known specimen of C. dollfusi.

Weber (1913) described Cynoglossus sibogae based on two specimens collected off Indonesia. Norman (1928) questioned whether C. sibogae was a junior synonym of C. brachycephalus Bleeker 1875. Menon (1977) regarded both C. sibogae and C. brachycephalus as synonyms of C. kopsii (Bleeker 1851). Later authors (e.g., Li and Wang 1995, Mohsin and Ambak 1996, Munroe 2000, Wang et al. 2016) consider C. sibogae to be a valid species distinct from C. kopsii and C. brachycephalus. Although further research is required to clarify the taxonomic status of these nominal species, for the purposes of this work, C. sibogae is regarded as a valid species.

Plagusia trulla (now C. trulla), described by Cantor (1849), has a complicated nomenclatural history. At least two other species, Cynoglossus borneensis Bleeker 1858 and C. sinicus Wu 1932, have been entangled in the synonymy of P. trulla (Menon 1977). In his global revision of the genus Cynoglossus, Menon (1977) incorrectly regarded C. borneensis as the senior synonym of Plagusia trulla. However, since C. trulla was described earlier than C. borneensis, this former species has precedence and C. trulla is the appropriate name for this taxon.  

Cynoglossus sinicus Wu 1932 is currently (Kottelat 2013) regarded as a junior synonym of C. trulla. According to Kottelat (2013), Li and Wang (1995) treated C. sinicus as specifically distinct (and valid) from C. borneensis (or from a species locally misidentified as C. borneensis). Given the taxonomic uncertainty regarding the specimens Li and Wang (1995) identified as C. borneensis, more work is needed to determine what species they actually had under consideration.

For the purpose of this assessment, the account of Cynoglossus trulla also includes information reported for C. borneensis and C. sinicus.

Paraplagusia guttata (Macleay 1878) has had a complex nomenclatural history. It has been considered a junior subjective synonym of Paraplagusia bilineata (Bloch 1787) by many authors, including Menon (1980) in his revision of the genus Paraplagusia. Chapleau and Renaud (1993) in their treatment of species of Paraplagusia from Australian waters also considered this species as a synonym of P. bilineata (Bloch 1787), as did Johnson (1999, 2010) and Larson et al. (2013). In contrast, Li and Wang (1995), Randall and Lim (2000), and Hutchins (2004) considered P. guttata as a valid species.
 
Paraplagusia bilineata (Bloch 1787) has had an equally complex nomenclatural history, with many nominal species of Paraplagusia placed in its synonymy. Likely, several of these nominal species are valid, but the taxonomic work to resolve this problem has not been conducted. Preliminary observations (T.A. Munroe unpublished data) indicate that P. guttata should be recognized as a valid species and it is therefore treated as such herein.

McCulloch (1907) originally described Symphurus strictus var. australis based on a single specimen collected in relatively deep water off southeastern Australia. This taxon is now regarded as a valid species, Symphurus australis.

Symphurus bathyspilus Krabbenhoft and Munroe 2003 was described from specimens collected in the Philippines and Indonesia. Other specimens tentatively identified as this species collected in other Indo-West Pacific localities likely represent a complex of at least six nominal species (M.-Y. Lee pers. comm. 2021). Further research is needed to evaluate the taxonomic status of these specimens, to better understand the diversity within this potential species complex, and to provide more accurate information on the distribution of S. bathyspilus (sensu Krabbenhoft and Munroe 2003).
This species was described on the basis of a single specimen, which has since been lost. As such, its taxonomic status remains questionable (Lee et al. 2013).

Symphurus gilesii was described from a single specimen collected in the Bay of Bengal (Alcock 1889). Later, Weber (1913), Weber and de Beaufort (1929), and Norman (1928, 1939) listed this species as occurring in the Kei Islands, Indonesia. Chabanaud (1957) recognized that the specimen from the Kei Islands represented an undescribed species, which he formally described as S. fallax. Subsequently, the type specimen of S. fallax has been lost (Desoutter et al. 2001) and some authors (e.g. Lee et al. 2013) have questioned the validity of S. fallax. For the purposes of this assessment, we consider the specimen from the Kei Islands to represent a species different from S. gilesii (Alcock 1889).

This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Symphurus microrhynchus (Munroe and Marsh 1997), but is now recognized as a valid species on the basis of morphological and molecular characteristics (Lee et al. 2016).

Originally described on the basis of a single specimen (Hubbs 1915), Symphurus hondoensis was subsequently considered by Matsubara (1955) to be a junior synonym of Symphurus strictus Gilbert 1905. Upon discovery of a second specimen of S. hondoensis, this species was redescribed and recognized as valid by Munroe and Amaoka (1998).

Norman (1939) recorded a specimen caught at JM Station 153 as Symphurus marmoratus. This damaged specimen was later described as a new species, Symphurus maldivensis, by Chabanaud (1955). No additional specimens have been reported, but S. maldivensis is currently regarded as valid (Munroe 1992, 2006, Adam et al. 1998). Additional specimens are needed to more properly assess the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

Weber (1913) described the nominal species, Aphoristia (= Symphurus) elongata. Unfortunately, Weber (1913) did not realize that elongata had already been used by Günther (1868) in naming another nominal species, Aphoristia (= Symphurus) ornata elongata. This latter name has priority. Therefore, Weber and de Beaufort (1929) proposed S. regani as the replacement name for the nominal species Aphoristia elongata Weber 1913.

Aphoristia (= Symphurus) woodmasoni Alcock 1889 was described on the basis of a single specimen collected off the Andaman Islands, India. Three additional specimens were later collected from the Bay of Bengal (Alcock 1892). Identifications of these specimens have been verified. Earlier records (Regan 1908, Norman 1928) that report this species from the Saya de Malha Bank are incorrect. These specimens were misidentified and later described by Chabanaud (1955c) as S. sayademalhensis. Additionally, other studies that have reported S. woodmasoni from Oman, Laccadive Islands, Indonesia, and the Philippines (e.g., Norman 1928, 1939; Chabanaud 1955a,b; Munroe 1992) also may not be based on specimens of this species. According to Chabanaud (1954, 1955c) and Krabbenhoft and Munroe (2003), these records may represent other tonguefish species. Likewise, the report of S. woodmasoni from the Philippines by Cabanban et al. (2010), which is based on the same series of specimens reported in Chabanaud (1955a,b), also may be in doubt. Resolution of taxonomic questions regarding the other specimens from beyond the Bay and Bengal and Andaman Sea, which were previously identified as S. woodmasoni, is necessary to establish the actual distribution of S. woodmasoni.
This species was reviewed by Allen and Burgess (1990).

According to Randall and Johnson (2007), specimens from Australia previously identified as Pardachirus poropterus are actually specimens of P. rautheri. Randall and Johnson (2007) also indicate that research is needed to clarify possible regional variations observed among specimens of P. poropterus, as these variations may reflect differences among members of a species complex, rather than population variation within a single species.
Revisonary work is required for the genus Stenogobius. This species is very similar to S. hoesei and S. watsoni.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius. This species may be synonymous with two other species from the same region.
This species has been confused with S. hasta in the past (Amir et al. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species requires verification.
This species is known from five specimens collected in Lago Budi, a coastal lagoon in Chile (Pequeño and Plaza 1987 ). The taxonomic status of this nominal species needs reevaluation.

Spinirhombus (now Pseudorhombus) ctenosquamis was described by Oshima in 1927 based on a single specimen collected at a fish market in Taiwan, which subsequently has been lost. The taxonomic status of this species is questionable. No other specimens have been reported by authors working on flatfishes of Taiwan (e.g., Chen and Weng 1965, Shao et al. 2008, Shao and Ho 2011).

Wu (1932) considered Pseudorhombus ctenosquamis as a synonym of P. cinnamoneus, but did not indicate that he had examined the type specimen. Norman (1934) provided an account for this species, but equivocated in noting that Wu (1932) considered it to be a synonym of P. cinnamoneus. Chen and Weng (1965) provided an account for this species, but all indications are that the information is based on that provided in the original description. Li and Wang (1995) considered this as a valid species. However, Randall and Lim (2000) do not include this species among the paralichthyids recorded from the South China Sea nor did Shao et al. (2008) list this species in their checklist of fishes of southern Taiwan. 

Given that no additional specimens have ever been recorded and authors working with the genus Pseudorhombus disagree, further research is required to establish the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

This species may be easily confused with Glyptocephalus kitaharae (Jang et al. 2016). An mtDNA analysis of specimens of Glyptocephalus stelleri from four widely separated areas throughout the Japanese Archipelago reported no significant genetic differentiation among samples from these four areas (Xiao et al. 2010).

Hippoglossoides punctatissima Steindachner 1879 has been placed by various authors in the genera Pleuronectes, Limanda, and Myzopsetta (see Fricke et al. 2021 for further details). The most recent systematic review of the Pleuronectidae considers this species a member of the genus Myzopsetta (Vinnikov et al. 2018), and this decision is followed herein.

Pleuronichthys cornutus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) was described based on several specimens collected off Japan. Later, Pleuronichthys lighti Wu 1929 was described based on a unique holotype collected near Amoy Island, China. The present whereabouts of this specimen is unknown. Subsequently, P. lighti was considered as a junior synonym of P. cornutus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) by several authors (Li and Wang 1995; Evseenko 2003, 2004; Suzuki et al. 2009). According to the taxonomic work of Yokogawa et al. (2014, 2016), both P. lighti and P. cornutus should be recognized as valid species. Molecular analyses conducted by Vinnikov et al. (2018) also support recognition of P. cornutus and P. lighti.

Pleuronichthys lighti Wu 1929 was described based on a unique holotype collected near Amoy Island, China. The present whereabouts of this specimen is unknown. Subsequently, P. lighti was considered as a junior synonym of P. cornutus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) from off Japan by several authors (Li and Wang 1995, Evseenko 2003, 2004, Suzuki et al. 2009). According to the taxonomic work of Yokogawa et al. (2014, 2016), both P. lighti and P. cornutus should be recognized as valid species. Molecular analyses conducted by Vinnikov et al. (2018) also support recognition of P. cornutus and P. lighti.
Guibord and Chapleau (2004) synonymized Nematops chui Fowler 1934 with Nematops macrochirus Norman 1931 after analyzing the only known specimen of the first nominal species.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.

Chabanaud (1930) described Aseraggodes beauforti based on two syntypes from the Timor Sea. Randall and Desoutter-Meninger (2007) later re-identified the smaller specimen as A. kaianus and designated the larger specimen as the lectotype of A. beauforti.

As reported in the literature, Aseraggodes cyaneus has a widespread distribution in the Indo-West Pacific (Alcock 1890, Quero and Desoutter 1990, Winterbottom and Anderson 1997, Munroe 2000, Munroe 2001, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, Fricke et al. 2018). However, the taxonomic status of such widely distributed subpopulations purportedly of this species needs further investigation. It is likely that a species complex is represented among these subpopulations.
Randall and Senou (2007) note that this species was previously identified as Aseraggodes xenicus by Matsubara and Ochiai (1963).

Synaptura swinhonis was described by Steindachner (1867) based on a single specimen collected off Hong Kong. Since that time, no other specimens of this nominal species have been reported in the literature, but it has been regarded as a valid species by most authors (e.g., Li and Wang 1995, Munroe 2000, Voronina 2019). Okamoto and Motomura (2021) tentatively consider Brachirus swinhonis (Steindachner 1867) as valid, pending further specimens from Hong Kong. At present, this species is considered valid pending further investigation.

The generic placement of Synaptura callizona Regan 1903 is uncertain. It has been placed in the genera Aesopia, Pseudaesopia, and Zebrias by various authors. The current name in the Catalog of Fishes is Zebrias callizona, but no references or justification are provided to support this listing. Stephens (2011), in an unpublished revision of Zebrias and related genera, concluded that Synaptura callizona Regan 1903 should be assigned to the genus Pseudaesopia, and this decision is recognized herein.

Desoutter et al. (2001) considered Soleichthys multifasciatus (Kaup 1858) to be a synonym of Soleichthys heterorhinos (Bleeker 1856), but it has since been considered to be a valid species (Muchhala and Munroe 2004, Munroe and Menke 2004, Randall and Munroe 2008).

Li and Wang (1995) considered Soleichthys nigrostriolatus (Steindachner and Kner 1870) to be a synonym of Soleichthys heterorhinos (Bleeker 1856). More recently, S. nigrostriolatus has been treated as a valid species (Muchhala and Munroe 2004, Munroe and Menke 2004, Randall and Munroe 2008).

This species was originally assigned to the genus Cryptops (Hardenberg 1931a); however, the genus name Cryptops was preoccupied. The species was subsequently reassigned to the genus Typhlachirus by Hardenberg (1931b).

There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Zebrias keralensis. These taxonomic issues have not been fully resolved. At present, both nominal species are considered valid (Fricke et al. 2019).

Whitley (1966) described a new sole from Australian waters as Strabozebrias munroi. Subsequently, this species was listed both in the genus Phyllichthys and in the genus Strabozebrias by Hutchins (2001). Munroe (2001), based on morphological and pigmentation features, considered this species as a member of the genus Phyllichthys. Stephens (2011), in an unpublished thesis, also considered Strabozebrias munroi Whitley 1966 as a member of the genus Phyllichthys, based on these morphological and pigmentation features. This decision has not been universally accepted, instead, several authors have recognized this species as a member of Zebrias (e.g. Hoese and Bray 2006, Bray 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, based on the information presented in Munroe (2001) and Stephens (2011), this species is considered a member of Phyllichthys.

Historically, a great deal of confusion has surrounded the species complex comprising Zebrias zebra (Bloch 1787), Zebrias zebrinus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846), Zebrias ommatura (Richardson 1846), and Zebrias fasciatus (Basilewsky 1855). Zebrias ommatura and Z. fasciatus have been regarded as junior subjective synonyms for both Z. zebra and Z. zebrinus by different authors. The more persistent problem involves the taxonomic status of Z. zebra (Bloch 1787) and Z. zebrinus (Temminck and Schlegel 1847). These have been considered synonymous by some authors (Ochiai 1963, Lindberg and Fedorov 1993, Li and Wang 1995, Kottelat 2013), whereas other authors (Wang et al. 2014) have regarded both as valid species. The most recent appraisal of these nominal species based on morphology and molecular data (Wang et al. 2014) concluded that both Z. zebra (Bloch 1787) and Z. zebrinus (Temminck and Schlegel 1847) are valid, while Z. ommatura  and Z. fasciatus are junior subjective synonyms of Z. zebrinus. These conclusions are followed herein.
This species is easily confused with other goatfish species, including Upeneus heemstra (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species has recently been described as distinct from A. spinifer, with which it has been confused (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2018).

Acanthistius patachonicus and A. brasilianus have been confused in the past, but are confirmed as separate species. Acanthistius brasilianus does not occur in Argentine waters (Irigoyen et al. 2008, 2010).
The taxonomic status of this nominal species needs to be investigated further (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2020).

This is a poorly known nominal species, described by Linnaeus (1758) from an unreported number of specimens taken at Ambon Island, Indonesia. No type specimens are known to exist. Additional reports of this nominal species are limited. In an overview of the Soleidae, Kaup (1858) determined that the diagnosis of this nominal species by Linnaeus (1758) was correct, but did not indicate whether additional specimens had been examined. Kaup (1858) transferred this nominal species to the genus Solea. Günther (1862) provided a brief synonymy and some information in a brief description of this nominal species, but again did not indicate whether further specimens were available or if his account was based only on the specimens reported in Linnaeus. Günther (1862) indicated that the typical specimens were 30 lines long (~6.3 cm). Weber and de Beaufort (1929) included this nominal species among those listed as doubtful species from the Indo-Australian Archipelago.


Several studies have reported this species from China. Jouan (1867) purportedly examined at least one specimen of this nominal species from Hong Kong. However, Wu (1932) determined that the identification of this species in Jouan (1867) was uncertain. Li and Wang (1995) further remarked that no specimen or description were supplied by Jouan (1867) and noted Wu’s (1932) report of the uncertainty of this record. Li and Wang (1995) provide a synonymy, counts from the original description, and a discussion of the historical literature for this nominal species. They provided no new information regarding specimens from Chinese waters. Their account of this nominal species primarily is a discussion of the historical literature on this nominal species, but no new information was presented to resolve the question regarding the validity of this nominal species. 


Although it is currently regarded as a valid species in the Catalog of Fishes, the limited available evidence raises doubts concerning the validity of this species. Research is needed to determine whether this nominal species is valid. For purposes of this assessment, only the information from the specimen(s) examined by Linneaus is considered.
Mangarinus waterousi belongs to a genus that has never been reviewed and it is uncertain whether it consists of one or several species throughout its range.
The species may be misidentified with other members of the Etmoperus lucifer clade (Ebert et al. 2017).
Sciaenia starksi is a junior synonym of S. wierneri (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2018).

There is significant taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species in part due to the damaged condition of the holotype and possible confusion with Kentrocapros flavofasciatus (Stewart and Roberts 2015).
This species was previously considered a synonym of Kentrocapros aculeatus (Mundy 2005).

Many authors have considered this species to be a junior synonym of Paralichthys brasiliensis, a species that is often confused with; however, these species can be distinguished by meristic characteristics and both are currently accepted as separate nominal species (Díaz de Astarloa et al. 2006).
Additional research is needed to determine the range extent of this species and its' systematic status (McMahan pers. comm. 2020).

Stolephorus waitei has long been considered the senior synonym of S. bataviensis and widely distributed in Indo-West Pacific (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Wongratana et al. 1999). A recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. bataviensis is a valid species and restricted the true S. waitei (reported as Stolephorus species A. in Whitehead et al. 1988) to Queensland, Australia (Hata et al. 2019).
This species is a member of the Cryptocentrus leucostictus complex (Hoese and Larson 2004).

Stolephorus babarani closely resembles S. bataviensis Hardenberg, 1933 and S. baweanensis Hardenberg, 1933. Stolephorus babarani was previously misidentified as S. waitei Jordan and Seale, 1926 (Hata et al. 2020).

Stolephorus bataviensis, originally described as S. insularis bataviensis, has historically been considered a junior synonym of S. waitei (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Wongratana et al. 1999). A recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. bataviensis is a valid species and restricted the true S. waitei to Queensland, Australia (Hata et al. 2019).

Stolephorus baweanensis, originally described as S. insularis baweanensis, has historically been considered a junior synonym of S. insularis (e.g., Whitehead et al. 1988, Kottelat 2013). A recent morphological and genetic review of ten nominal species of Stolephorus concluded that S. baweanensis is a valid species and that some specimens previously identified as S. waitei are S. baweanensis (Hata et al. 2019).
Stolephorus tamilensis is closely related to S. andhraensis (Gangan et al. 2020).

This species was recently described as a new species in the genus Thrissina, distinct from T. vitrirostris (Hata and Motomura 2019). There remains some disagreement as to the validity of the genera Thryssa and Thrissina. Kottelat (2013) regarded the genus Thyrssa as a new spelling for, and a junior synonym of, Thrissa and gave precedence to Thrissina over simultaneous synonyms Xenengraulis and Scutengraulis. However, Thryssa is regarded as independent of Thrissa by Fricke et al. (2020), and for the sake of stability, retained the genus Thryssa.

This species was recently described as a new species in genus Thrissina, distinct from T. vitrirostris (Hata and Motomura 2019). There remains some disagreement as to the validity of the genera Thryssa and Thrissina. Kottelat (2013) regarded the genus Thyrssa as a new spelling for, and a junior synonym of, Thrissa and gave precedence to Thrissina over simultaneous synonyms Xenengraulis and Scutengraulis. However, Thryssa is regarded as independent of Thrissa by Fricke et al. (2020), and for the sake of stability, retained the genus Thryssa.

Other than the original collection (Bloch and Schneider 1801), nothing is known about this nominal species. Norman (1934) regarded this species as a junior synonym of Bothus lunatus. It was not listed among the species of Citharichthys in Gutherz (1967) field guide to the bothid flatfishes of the Western Atlantic. Munroe (2003) did not consider this species in his treatment of the flatfishes of the Greater Caribbean, nor did Robertson and Van Tassell (2019) include this species in the online checklist. However, it is listed in Paepke (1999) and considered a valid species in the Catalog of Fishes (Fricke et al. 2021). It is assessed here but the taxonomic status of this nominal species needs to be investigated.

Stolephorus tri was originally described as Engraulis tri by Bleeker (1852). Although Whitehead et al. (1988) and Wongratana et al. (1999) listed no name as a synonym of the nominal species, Hata et al. (2019) regarded Stolephorus insularis Hardenberg, 1931 (previously regarded as a valid species) and Stolephorus baganensis megalops (previously regarded as a junior synonym of Stolephorus baganensis and inadvertently misquoted as S. b. macrops) as the junior synonyms of S. tri. The applicable scientific name for the species regarded as S. insularis by Whitehead et al. (1988) and Wongratana et al. (1999) is newly regarded as Stolephorus bengalensis (Dutt and Babu Rao, 1959), which was previously regarded as a junior synonym of S. baganensis in Hata et al. (2019).
Weigmann et al. (2020) revised the genus Pliotrema, describing this species and Pliotrema kajae as new species, distinct from Pliotrema warreni.
Weigmann et al. (2020) revised the genus Pliotrema, describing this species and Pliotrema annae as new species, distinct from Pliotrema warreni.

authority: Quattro, Driggers III, Grady, Ulrich & Roberts, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This cryptic species is most closely related to the Scalloped Hammerhead (Sphyrna lewini), and is morphologically distinguishable by the number of precaudal vertebrae (Quattro et al. 2013).

Genetic studies indicate that this species should be synonymized to Abudefduf saxatilis (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010). It is provisionally regarded as a valid species (A. hoefleri) until current genetic studies are published.

The morphological characteristics, ecology and distribution of A. celebesensis overlap broadly with those of both A. interioris and A. luzonensis making taxonomic distinction difficult in situ. The main difference is the ano-dorsal length which is measured as a percentage of the total length (TL) of the eel. In A. celebesensis, this value is between 6.0–11.9 according to Aoyama et al. (2000). The ADL/%TL of A. celebesensis has been found to overlap with other tropical anguillid species including A. interioris, A. marmorata, A. borneensis, A. bengalensis and A. obscura based on both morphology and genetic analyses (Sugeha et al. 2006b). Sugeha (2010) reported the range of total vertebrae and ano-dorsal vertebrae of this species found in Central Sulawesi (Indonesia) were 100–106 (Mean±SD = 102.86 ± 1.13) and 6–13 (9.48 ± 1.11), respectively. Further, ADL/%TL of the species was 6.00–17.65 with an average of 10.41 (SD = 1.61) (Sugeha 2010).

DNA sequencing has indicated admixture between A. megastoma and A. marmorata in some individuals from Vanuatu (Schabetsberger et al. 2015), American Samoa, and Bougainville (Gubili et al. 2018), and further observations of intermediate dentition suggests hybridisation (Schabetsberger et al. 2017). Samples collected from various expeditions across the Indo-Pacific also revealed another hybrid between A. megastoma and A. obscura (Barth et al. 2019).

The skin is grey to yellowish and more or less spotted with brown or black. It can be sometimes uniformly brownish red on the flanks and the back. The belly is white. Young specimens are grey and do not have spots. This species is also characterised by having 108–114 vertebrae (Smith 1999, Watanabe et al. 2011, Froese and Pauly 2012, Hewavitharane et al. 2017). Hewavitharane et al. (2017) found anodorsal ratios of A. megastoma and A. marmorata do not overlap, with values for anodorsal length (measured as a percentage of the total length) ranging between 8.2–12% and 14–17%, respectively, suggesting this is the only external morphological character that can distinguish these species.

Wanatabe et al. (2011) suggested A. megastoma may be separated into two subpopulations, eastern and western, within the western South Pacific due to statistically significant total vertebrae counts. Consistent results found by Hewavitharane et al. (2017) for vertebrae counts, further strengthens this hypothesis. Although Hewavitharane et al. (2017) adds considerably to the sample size supporting this hypothesis, these studies are based on relatively few specimens. Therefore, there is still a possibility this species may consist a single panmictic population in the South Pacific (Schabetsberger et al. 2018).

The Pacific Shortfin Eel, Anguilla obscura, belongs to the group of anguillids which have a short dorsal fin which originates slightly before the anus. This species most closely resembles A. australis and A. bicolor, from which it can be distinguished with certainty only by the number of vertebrae of which A. obscura typically has between 102 and 108. At the glass eel stage, this species can be potentially be distinguished from geographically overlapping A. marmorata and A. megastoma through caudal fin pigmentation, as distinctive patterns allow differentiation (Hewavitharane et al. 2017).

Anguilla interioris is generally considered to be most similar in appearance to Anguilla celebesensis, Anguilla luzonensis and Anguilla megastoma. The distance between the dorsal fin anterior margin and the anus (ADL) in A. interioris is 12.5–13.5% of total length (TL), whereas for A. celebesensis it is 7.5–10.5% of TL, with all other characteristics being almost equal (Silfvergrip 2009).  There does seem to be regional variation in this, as according to Sugeha (2010), A. interioris glass eel recruiting to the Poso River estuary had an ADL of 14.81–17.65% of TL. Without molecular identification, it is practically impossible to distinguish between specimens of A. interioris from A. celebesensis and A. luzonensis with certainty (Silfvergrip 2009). Differences in caudal fin pigmentation have also been documented between A. interioris and A. celebesensis (Sugeha 2010, Shirotori et al. 2016). This presents a possible diagnostic character, although at yellow eel stage they are unidentifiable. A. interioris can be distinguished from A. megastoma by the number of vertebrae: A. interioris typically has between 100 and 106 vertebrae and A. megastoma, 108–116.
This species was recently described from 20 specimens and is morphologically similar to Encrasicholina pseudoheteroloba (Hata and Motomura 2020).

This species was recently described and is closely related to T. chefuensis (Günther 1874). There remains some disagreement as to the validity of the genera Thryssa and Thrissina. Kottelat (2013) regarded the genus Thryssa as a new spelling for, and a junior synonym of, Thrissa and gave precedence to Thrissina over simultaneous synonyms Xenengraulis and Scutengraulis. However, Thryssa is regarded as independent of Thrissa by Fricke et al. (2020), and for the sake of stability, the genus Thryssa is retained.

Previously considered to also occur in the Northwest Pacific, a separate species that is likely endemic to the Northwest Pacific, that is Squalus formosus, has now been split from S. blainville and S. blainville occurs only in the eastern Atlantic, Mediterranean and Black Sea (White and Iglésias 2013). This species has a historically unstable nomenclature that has confused its identification with other Squalus spp. across its range (Veríssimo et al. 2017).
This species is newly described from old preserved material (Moore et al. 2020).
Bahaba polykladiskos should be classified under the genus Boesemania (N.L. Chao in prep. 2019).
This species is often confused with other Johnius spp. (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2016).

This recently described species can be distinguished from the regional congener the Yellowspotted Skate (Leucoraja wallacei) by its elongated snout and a dorsal surface pattern of a single ocelli at the mid-base of each pectoral fin, paired small white spots, and no banding on its tail (Ebert and Leslie 2019).

This recently described species is distinguished by a lack of mid-dorsal thorns, three pairs of white blotches on the dorsal disc surface, and dark bands on the mid-ventral line of the tail (Misawa et al. 2020).

This recently described species can be distinguished from its most closely-related regional congener, the Mangrove Whipray (Urogymnus granulatus) by a more angular snout, no white flecks on the dorsal surface, a uniformly white ventral surface with no broad black margin, and a longer tail (Last et al. 2016a).

The type specimen, lodged in the Museum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, has been examined by one of the assessors (P. Last) and is readily distinguished from the single congener (Sympterichthys moultoni) by absence of dermal spinules on illicium, meristic counts, and elongated second spine of dorsal fin; and from all other known handfish species by the combination of skin surface with covering of spiny scales, thin illicium of medium length, relatively deep body, 9 pectoral-fin rays, 9 anal-fin rays, and 22 vertebrae (Last and Gledhill 2009). Although the holotype was somewhat damaged and the number of specimens limited for both species within this genus, there is no taxonomic uncertainty. In addition to distinct morphometric and meristic differences, distributional disjunction frequently occurs within this group in particular (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).
